Hans Namuth was not initially interested in the work of [[Jackson Pollock]], but was convinced by his teacher Alexey Brodovitch that Pollock was an important painter.<ref name="npg"/> In July 1950, Namuth approached Pollock and asked to photograph the artist working in his studio. Pollock agreed, encouraged by his wife, [[Lee Krasner]], who was aware of the importance of media coverage.<ref name="npg"/> The resulting images helped to demystify Pollock's famous "drip" technique of painting, revealing it to be a deliberative process rather than a random splashing of paint.<ref name="oconnor">{{cite journal | last = O'Connor |first = Francis V. |title = Hans Namuth's Photographs of Jackson Pollock as Art Historical Documentation |accessdate=2007-08-31 |journal = Art Journal |pages = pp. 48â49 | publisher = College Art Association |month = Fall |year = 1979 |volume = 39 | url = http://links.jstor.org/sici?sici=0004-3249%28197923%2939%3A1%3C48%3AHNPOJP%3E2.0.CO%3B2-9 |issue = 1 |doi = 10.2307/776327 | jstor = 10.2307/776327}}</ref> They "helped transform Pollock from a talented, cranky loner into the first media-driven superstar of American contemporary art, the jeans-clad, chain-smoking poster boy of [[abstract expressionism]]," according to culture critic Ferdinand Protzman.<ref name="protzman">{{cite news |work = [[The Washington Post]] |title =
